instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1989: What is A1989? A1989 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2018, 2019 with EMC 3124, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00850..
definitions.820-00850: What is 820-00850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Hi, I have a board that is only drawing 5V on all USB-C ports getting 0.168A on two ports, then 0.134A on one port, then 0.026A on another.
After taking out the board and ports it appears one of the ports on each side is covered in junk. I am currently using a fresh port and getting 0.137A

I do not have the board view or schematics for this board. There also appears to be no visible corrosion/signs of liquid damage.
No voltage on any of the inductors, the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> that I've plugged the board into outputs 3.25V 5V 1V 0.9V on the caps around it
Any help is appreciated.

I have attached thermal pictures of the board. Front and backside of the only hot spot and one of the whole thing.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
All USB-C ports must have the same behaviour.
Check schematic/boardview and specify for each <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chip, LDO voltages and diode mode readings on the same power rails; 1x1V1, 2x1V8, 1x3V3 (4 in total).
Be aware, 1V1 LDO will only appear on the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chip corresponding to powered port.
[URL unfurl="true"]https://drive.google.com/file/d/1fJWssZ1-ujHB8dnp_zrasRkcN2RKTv8Y/view?usp=sharing[/URL]

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Hi, thank you for replying.
Took me a second to understand but I believe I got the right measurements.
All diode measurements were with the board unpowered, and red to ground.
Diode measurements are after the LDO

<CHIP>U3200</CHIP>:
1.8V LDOA,  0.517
1.799V LDOD, 0.071
2.3mV 1v1 LDO, 0.509
3.28V 3v3 LDO, 0.065

<CHIP>U3100</CHIP>:
No Voltage on any
0.527 1v8 LDOA
0.518 1v1 LDO
0.018 3v3 LDO
0.047 1V8 LDOD

UB400:
1.8V LDOA, 0.532
1.8 LDOD, 0.484
3.35V 3v3 LDO, 0.514
0 1v1 LDO, 0.513

UB300:
0V 1v8 LDOA, 0.525
0V 1v1 LDO, 0.518
2.47V 3v3 LDO, 0.062
300mV 1V8 LDOD, 0.025

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Next time, keep some logic when you write the values; this will help us a lot.
Change <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>/200 and UB300.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message: Can you please elaborate on what you mean? I tried to explain everything as clearly as possible.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Write the values in the same order for all chips.
Is more easy to compare, don't you think?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message: I apologize. Will do next time.
